Award.AwardTitle: Advancing Geospatial Thinking and Technologies in Grades 9-12: Citizen Mapping, Community Engagement, and Career Preparation in STEM

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Given recent advancements in geospatial technologies and the expanding geospatial technology industry, this project is timely in its focus on spatial thinking and strengthening geospatial technology skills among high school students. Students will investigate real world issues in the context of their own neighborhoods through citizen mapping activities. Students will use a variety of data collection devices, including GPS units, georeferencing cameras, and smartphones, along with secondary data, to investigate issues that students perceive as significant for their communities. Students will do field work on topics ranging from the distribution of grocery stores to environmental hazards and the conditions of local sidewalks, street lights and crosswalks, or other physical conditions impacting the community. Students will analyze their data and use on-line, open-source mapping applications to produce visualizations of the phenomena they are investigating.

This study includes students at an inner city high school in the Toledo, Ohio metropolitan area. Students will participate in summer workshops designed to introduce them to recent advances in geospatial technologies, especially in relation to understanding their communities and preparing them for the STEM workforce of the future. Students will be guided through the scientific processes of synthesis, analysis, and interpretation, and will input data they have produced as volunteered geographic information (VGI) into open-source mapping programs to produce maps for civic action that they will present to key individuals and organizations in the area. They will take a pre- and post-spatial thinking ability test (STAT) to assess changes in their spatial thinking knowledge and skills, as well as a pre- and post-sketch map of their neighborhoods to analyze changes in their perceptions of the community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A primary goal of this research project was to create an experiential learning curriculum model designed to enhance spatial thinking and community engagement as well as to provide technology rich experiences and connections to career paths among traditionally underrepresented groups in STEM. During two summer workshops, citizen mapping of student-identified local challenges was used to enhance their spatial skills and knowledge of the community. In addition, the students experienced an increase in awareness of educational pathways and careers in STEM that use geospatial technologies, a high-growth area according to the U.S. Department of Labor. The aim was to create a curricular model that can be used in diverse educational settings in STEM and social science disciplines.

 

We constructed a framework for including the geographies affecting students' lives to increase their engagement in the community and in STEM education. Experiential learning provided a platform for introducing them to geospatial technologies through citizen mapping and fieldwork, to prepare them to think critically and spatially about issues at larger geographic scales beyond their local community and empower them to be active citizens. We integrated a problem-based, authentic learning experience that focuses on real-world topics that students care about, while using citizen mapping as a tool to foster an open inquiry approach to learning.

 

We created an expanded version of an existing 5-E experiential learning curricular model. The core of our curriculum model is represented by three E's: Engage, Explore, and Explain, while we added Apply, Connect (to careers), and Extend (Figure 1). The remainder of the model includes stages that are designed to scaffold teaching and learning by providing a focus question, overview, links to disciplinary standards, learning targets, background information, and practical sources for potential enhancements. The curriculum criteria includes opportunities for revealing what students already know and understand, integrating what students want to know and why, engaging students authentically with careers, addressing disciplinary standards, using a multi-disciplinary approach, integrating geospatial technology, and supporting student research and problem-solving.

 

We demonstrated to both researchers and teachers that geospatial technology can be used in innovative ways to address social issues as well as scientific problems. This can be seen in the curriculum modules that were created based on topics proposed by students during our summer workshops, including green (open) space, crime, housing, youth employment, viewsheds and historical geography, and parks and community gardens. These experiential learning modules can be found on the project website, including detailed instructions for teachers, potential modifications or adaptations, and student worksheets for use in the classroom (http://www.utoledo.edu/research/advancing-geospatial-thinking/curriculum.html).

 

In regard to broader impacts, at the local level the workshops empowered the participating students with the knowledge and tools for enhancing their communities as well as their individual lives by exposing them to the uses and applications of technology in a rapidly growing field with substantial educational and employment opportunities. The methods and tools used to engage students in this endeavor can be applied in STEM and social science disciplines throughout the United States.

 

Another important impact was our effort to raise awareness of the importance of integrating connections to STEM education and career paths in the curriculum. We purposively included explicit careers connections in our curriculum design criteria, and provided examples for how to do this in our curriculum modules. We aimed to find effective ways to engage students in diverse educational settings to raise awareness of the value of STEM education and career paths for improving society.

 

Finally, spatial citizenship education is an expanding area within STEM. Through this NSF project, we created a framework for including the geographies affecting students' lives to increase their engagement in the community and in STEM and related social science disciplines, such as geography. We proposed a model for including students' geographies in STEM education, which promotes critical thinking, expands students' spatial narratives of their communities, empowers them as citizens, and prepares them to think beyond the local scale to address 21st century challenges.
